critique: This document establishes a Textile Labor Relations Board and outlines procedures for regulating work assignments in the cotton, silk, and wool textile industries. It appears to be an executive order issued under the authority of the National Industrial Recovery Act. The order aims to regulate the 'stretch-out' system, which seems to involve increasing work assignments. It establishes a process for employers to seek authorization for increasing work assignments, involving petitions, waiting periods, and potential hearings. It also allows employee representatives to challenge existing work assignments if they involve excessive effort. The order centralizes decision-making through district impartial chairmen and a Textile Work Assignment Board. It also appears to be pro-labor, giving them power to challenge work assignments. It does not touch on immigration, civil liberties, or social inclusion. It does not expand executive power beyond what was already granted in the NIRA. It does not touch on federalism. It does regulate the economy.
